Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance is meeting a new person who seems shy and nervous in a social setting.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was at a small gathering, chatting with a few people I barely knew. One of them, a quiet guy named Ben, looked especially uneasy, fidgeting with his sleeves and barely making eye contact. I remembered my role as an acquaintance—to be friendly, to help him feel comfortable. I smiled, tried to draw him into the conversation, and asked gentle questions. Just as he started to open up, my phone buzzed. It was a reminder: I needed to check the ambulance’s first-aid kit before my shift started in half an hour. As an ambulance driver, I couldn’t risk missing expired supplies or missing items; lives could depend on it. But if I left now, Ben might feel abandoned or rejected, reinforcing his anxiety. I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me—one demanding compassion and presence, the other demanding responsibility and precision. My mind raced, torn between staying to support Ben and leaving to fulfill my duty as an ambulance driver.
